sect1.title: Commands and Command Prompts Used in This Guide
sect1.para: As a &ceph; cluster administrator, you will be configuring and adjusting the cluster behavior by running specific commands. There are several types of commands you will need:

sect2.title: &salt; Related Commands
sect2.para: These commands help you to deploy &ceph; cluster nodes, run commands on several (or all) cluster nodes at the same time, or assist you when adding or removing cluster nodes. The most frequently used commands are ceph-salt and ceph-salt config. You need to run &salt; commands on the &smaster; node as &rootuser;. These commands are introduced with the following prompt:

sect2.title: &ceph; Related Commands
sect2.para: These are lower level commands to configure and fine tune all aspects of the cluster and its gateways on the command line, for example ceph, cephadm, rbd, or radosgw-admin.
The safer and recommended option is to create a more restrictive individual key for each administrator user and put it in a directory where the users can read it, for example:

tip.title: Path to &ceph; Keys
tip.para: To use a custom admin user and keyring, you need to specify the user name and path to the key each time you run the ceph command using the -n client.USER_NAME and --keyring PATH/TO/KEYRING options.
To avoid this, include these options in the CEPH_ARGS variable in the individual users' ~/.bashrc files.

sect2.title: General Linux Commands
sect2.para: Linux commands not related to &ceph;, such as mount, cat, or openssl, are introduced either with the &prompt.cephuser; or &prompt.root; prompts, depending on which privileges the related command requires.
